awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling and Inference for Spatiotemporal Climate Impacts on Complex Ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
In many hierarchical dynamical systems, synchrony between multiple fluctuating variables (i.e., correlations or other similarities in fluctuations between variables through time) is more important than the individual variables themselves. For instance, a neuron may fire only when all of its input neurons fire synchronously, or the electrical grid may crash only when demands of multiple users become synchronized, producing total-usage spikes. Ecosystems can show this type of dependency on synchrony. Ecosystems include multiple trophic levels, with population signals from lower levels often being spatially aggregated to affect higher levels and human concerns such as fisheries. For instance, a predator is only harmed if its prey are scarce over its whole hunting area. And human fish exploitation is only reduced if fish decline synchronously everywhere. For systems of this type, it is primarily the synchronous components of signals that matter in the average signal that affects the next hierarchical level - non-synchronous components tend to cancel in the spatial average. Thus, spatial synchrony of population dynamics is very important to ecosystem dynamics generally. Spatial synchrony of population dynamics has been widely observed in organisms as diverse as mammals and protists, at distances up to thousands of kilometers. Synchrony is closely related to large-scale outbreaks and shortages. Synchrony has conservation implications because populations are at greater risk of simultaneous extinction if they are simultaneously rare. But in spite of the importance of synchrony in ecology, possible impacts of climate change on synchrony are very little studied. In this context, climate change constitutes not just warming, but also changes in other statistical aspects of environmental signals. It is also unknown the extent to which synchrony, and climate-change-induced changes therein, can be transmitted through predator-prey interacts and hence throughout entire food webs in complex patterns. The goals of this research are: (1) to develop mathematical models and statistics to build understanding of how potential changes in synchrony induced by climate change will ramify through complex ecosystems; (2) and to develop mathematical models and use them to understand the consequences of changes in synchrony for a widely observed empirical pattern called Taylor's law, a phenomenon fundamental to spatial ecology and applied in a variety of areas including fisheries management, conservation, and agriculture. Researchers will also strive, as time allows, to understand the consequences of changes in synchrony for species extinction risk.

To meet goal (1) above, the researchers will perform stochastic-process modeling in a network context, to understand how changes in synchrony should theoretically cascade through complex species interaction networks; and will develop statistical methods combining wavelets and statistical path analysis, to be used to help infer how synchrony cascades through empirical interaction networks. A vector autoregressive moving average modelling framework will be constructed consisting of multiple habitat patches, with several species interacting within patches, migrating between patches, and being affected by a stochastic environment in each patch. For each species independently, dispersal and/or environmental synchronizing effects can be independently set to act directly on the species as synchronizing influences, or not. A given species may also be synchronized through its interactions with other synchronized species. The primary utility of the models is to make it possible to derive analytically, for each species, the relative importance of these direct and trophically-mediated synchronizing effects, thereby understanding the nature of trophic transmission of synchrony through the network. To meet goal (2) above, researchers will use the theory of ergodic stationary stochastic processes to represent population levels at different locations. If time allows, consequences of synchrony for extinction risk will be assessed through mathematical analysis within a classic stochastic matrix modelling framework, expanded to represent multiple populations across space.

por.por_cntn:
Three new mathematical/statistical dimensions of spatial synchrony and their importance

 

"Spatial synchrony" refers to the tendency for populations of the same species in different locations, sometimes widely separated, to exhibit related or similar abundance fluctuations through time. Spatial synchrony (henceforth, simply "synchrony") is a ubiquitous characteristic of population dynamics, having been documented worldwide in hundreds of taxa from clades as diverse as fish, protists, and mammals, at separation distances up to thousands of kilometers. Synchrony can be caused by dispersal between populations or through the influences of spatially correlated environmental fluctuations. Synchrony relates to numerous research topics and applications of fundamental importance in ecology, including ecosystem stability, species extinction, and pest and disease outbreaks.

 

Synchrony work prior to this research project had almost exclusively used correlations to measure similarity of fluctuations of distinct populations. In this project, we explored three major new statistical or mathematical ?dimensions? of synchrony which correspond to new features of synchrony which had previously been seldom or never exploited. The new ?dimensions? of synchrony are its timescale structure, its geography, and asymmetries of association in the tails of population distributions. We have developed new statistical and mathematical approaches to studying synchrony along these dimensions, and we have exploited these new approaches to develop much improved understanding of the populations and the ecosystems of which they are a part. Work funded by this grant was wide-ranging and extensive, including over 35 publications in peer-reviewed mathematical, statistical, and ecological journals, as well as open-source professional-grade software packages, and numerous open-science data and workflow contributions. Below we describe each dimension in turn, and then list a few of the discoveries made.

 

Timescale structure in synchrony. Synchrony can differ according to the timescale of measurement. For instance, one might expect annual average pest populations in separated locations to fluctuate similarly through time, if annual average abundances are influenced by large-scale climatic factors; but daily deviations from annual averages, of population abundances or activity levels, might depend on purely local factors and so be unrelated in the distinct locations. We have now widely documented timescale structure in synchrony in diverse taxa, including aphid crop pests, grassland plants, giant kelp, marine and freshwater plankton, white-tailed deer, cicadas, and lepidopteran crop pests. Timescale structuring appears to be an essentially ubiquitous feature of synchrony.

 

Geography of synchrony. It was well known that synchrony between distant populations tends to be weaker than synchrony between nearby populations, but we have discovered an enormous amount of additional geographic structuring of synchrony: some locations are much more synchrony, and other much less, than one might expect given their distances of separation. We have studied geographies of synchrony in diverse taxa and have identified the four main mechanisms of geographies of synchrony.

 

Asymmetries of tail association. It turns out that some populations can be much more synchronous when they crash to low levels than when they explode to high abundances, and others can exhibit the reverse tendency. Populations are not only synchronous or asynchronous; in fact patterns of synchrony as measured during extreme events can differ markedly from those measured in normal times. We have discovered that this kind of asymmetry of association is not only a widespread feature of populations, but also occurs very generally across many other types of ecological and environmental data. The 2008 financial crisis has been blamed on failures to account for such statistical patterns in economic data. Related catastrophes may, in theory, also occur in ecosystems. We have begun developing appropriate approaches to understand asymmetries of association in ecological data to outline their possible impacts on services that ecosystems provide to humans.    

 

All three of these new dimensions of synchrony represent major new phenomena in their own right. For instance, geographies of synchrony are extremely strong, and span continental scales. But our work has additionally led to several major advances through application of our new approaches; we here list a few examples. First, prior to our work, statistical inference of the causes of synchrony was considered difficult. Our timescale and geographic approaches have essentially solved this problem ? when sufficient data are available, environmental and dispersal-related causes of synchrony are now straightforwardly and routinely identified. Second, our work provides some of the first examples that synchrony is changing as a consequence of climatic changes. Thanks in part to our work, changes in synchrony are now recognized as another of the major impact of climate change. Third, population "cycles" (i.e., regular, periodic oscillations) have fascinated ecologists for a century, and are important for wildlife management. We discovered a new mechanism of cycles which relates to synchrony, and described its importance for deer in Wisconsin and for deer-vehicle collisions. Finally, our work on asymmetric associations has implications for species extinction risk, trophic mismatches, and the stability of ecosystems and widespread populations such as giant kelp.
